awd_titl_txt: Structure of Mappings in Several Complex Variables and Cauchy-Riemann Geometry
awd_abstract_narration:
The study of invariant geometries is an important part of mathematics. Different types of invariant geometries arise in different areas of mathematics, e.g., in several complex variables (SCV), partial differential equations (PDE), and algebraic, complex, and differential geometry. In this research project, the principal investigator Peter Ebenfelt will investigate a particular geometry that arises in the study of SCV, and which has also deep connections with contemporary topics in mathematical physics such as quantum field theory and string theory, as well as applications in, e.g., systems engineering and control theory. Tools that are needed for this study come from a variety of different areas in mathematics, such as complex analysis, PDE, and differential geometry, and the techniques and tools developed in this study influence these areas as well.  Ebenfelt expects that the project will also provide interesting research topics for graduate students and postdocs. The seminar activity that results from the project should be stimulating for both students and other researchers.

The goal of this mathematics research project by Peter Ebenfelt is to study geometric, analytic, and algebraic aspects of generic real submanifolds in complex varieties (more generally, of Cauchy-Riemann (CR) structures) and their mappings. Ebenfelt will consider questions regarding existence, uniqueness, and regularity of CR maps, as well as related questions that arise in connection with this study. He will consider the context of CR maps of a Levi nondegenerate hypersurface into a nondegenerate hyperquadric of higher dimension. This study will enhance our understanding of the CR submanifold structure of the hyperquadrics, which constitute the flat models in the theory of Levi nondegenerate hypersurfaces. The proposed work should also provide insight into how the local CR geometry of such hypersurfaces (in principle completely encoded in the CR curvature tensor) affects various properties, such as notions of nondegeneracy and rigidity, of their CR maps. Ebenfelt will also continue his study of CR maps between generic submanifolds of infinite type by investigating the prolongation of the system defining CR maps to a singular Pfaffian system on the jet bundle. He will, in particular, focus on understanding the recently discovered phenomenon that for infinite type hypersurfaces the biholomorphic, formal, and smooth CR equivalence classifications are different. He will also study a conjecture regarding finite jet determination of local automorphisms. These investigations are expected to shed new light on the nature of CR maps between infinite type manifolds, and lead to a better understanding of the Pfaffian systems arising in this context. Ebenfelt will also continue his work on normal forms for infinite type hypersurfaces in complex 2-space. Finally, Ebenfelt will study CR invariants on unit circle bundles over Kähler manifolds, specifically Cartan's umbilical tensor in the 3-dimensional case and those arising in the expansions of the Bergman and Szegö kernels. He intends to develop new methods for detecting umbilical points on general 3-dimensional CR manifolds, and resolve an open problem regarding existence of umbilical points on compact CR manifolds embedded in complex 2-space.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit. The main achievement in terms of intellectual merit of this project has been a deeper understanding of the role of the boundary in the overall analysis and geometry of complex manifolds and their mappings. Complex analysis and geometry of complex manifolds are central to mathematics and find applications in and deep connections with modern topics in mathematical physics, such as string theory, quantum field theory, and general relativity, as well as in systems engineering. The boundaries of complex manifolds inherit a CR structure from the complex structure of the manifold that reflect the interior geometry and the behavior of functions and fields as they approach the boundary. The main results in this project have multiple prongs. One group of results concerns the classification of obstruction flat boundaries of strictly pseudoconvex domains. Obstruction flatness refers to the property that the logarithmic potential of the complete Kahler-Einstein metric extends smoothly to the boundary; the obstruction to such extension vanishes if the boundary is obstruction flat. The prototype of a domain with obstruction flat boundary is the unit ball. One of the results obtained asserts that the unit ball in complex 2-space is the only such domain (up to biholomorphism) under small deformations in 2-space. A second group of results in this project concerns the existence of umbilical points, i.e., points where a CR manifold is osculated to a higher-than-expected order by the model hyperquadric, on compact CR manifolds in complex 2-space. This question is a purely “low-dimensional CR geometry” question, as existence is not expected in higher dimensions. One result asserts the existence of umbilical points for domains with circular symmetries, while another establishes that existence in fact fails in general, thereby answering a long-standing question by Chern-Moser. A third group of results concerns the structure of real hypersurfaces of infinite type in complex 2-space. 

Broader Impact. This project has had an impact on the several complex variables community in general, as the PI has lectured extensively on the results obtained and the ideas and methods behind them at international conferences and workshops. The PI has mentored two postdoc (Sean Curry and Hang Xu) in the reporting period, and also one Ph.D. student (Soumya Ganguly), who has just completed his first year of graduate studies. Sean is now a tenure track assistant professor at Oklahoma State University. The mathematical basis for the interactions with Sean, Hang, and Soumya have been the problems and questions studied under this project, as well as problems and questions that grew out of these discussions.

 


Last Modified: 10/29/2021
Modified by: Peter Ebenfelt
